title: Drivers causing blinding incidents on UK roads with illegal headlights

title_detail.value: Drivers causing blinding incidents on UK roads with illegal headlights

summary: Motoring campaigners say the trend to replace worn-out halogen bulbs with LED 'upgrades' may be a key factor in the epidemic of blinding incidents on Britain's roads.

summary_detail.value: Motoring campaigners say the trend to replace worn-out halogen bulbs with LED 'upgrades' may be a key factor in the epidemic of blinding incidents on Britain's roads.

author: Nick Constable
generated_summary: Research suggests that a growing trend of drivers in the UK illegally fitting super-bright LED headlights into cars not designed for them is contributing to an increase in blinding incidents on the roads. Motoring campaigners and the RAC highlight that these LED 'upgrades' are often replacing older halogen bulbs, causing significant glare and posing a safety risk. A survey found that 91% of drivers have experienced dazzling from headlights, with nearly 7% avoiding night driving due to the issue. The Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency states that LED bulbs can only be legally used if fitted as standard in new cars. The government has been urged to investigate further, as many drivers may be unaware of the illegality and safety implications of these modifications.

title: Who is Patrick Stewart? Everything you need to know about Rangers' new CEO

title_detail.value: Who is Patrick Stewart? Everything you need to know about Rangers' new CEO

summary: The former interim CEO at Manchester United is set to land the role at Rangers.

summary_detail.value: The former interim CEO at Manchester United is set to land the role at Rangers.

author: Joshua Barrie
generated_summary: Patrick Stewart, a former interim CEO at Manchester United, is set to become the new CEO of Rangers FC, succeeding James Bisgrove who left the club in May. Stewart, originally from Aberdeen, has a background in law and has worked with UEFA's marketing agency for the Champions League. At Manchester United, he served as General Counsel and Company Secretary, later becoming an executive and interim CEO. His appointment at Rangers comes amid a period of executive restructuring at the club, with Malcolm Offord also expected to be named as the new Chairman. Stewart's role will involve stabilizing the club's leadership and potentially appointing a sporting director to oversee football operations.

title: Former Manchester United CEO set to land Rangers chief executive role

title_detail.value: Former Manchester United CEO set to land Rangers chief executive role

summary: Rangers are expected to name former Manchester United chief Patrick Stewart as their new chief executive officer.

summary_detail.value: Rangers are expected to name former Manchester United chief Patrick Stewart as their new chief executive officer.

author: Christopher Jack
generated_summary: Former Manchester United executive Patrick Stewart is set to become the new CEO of Rangers FC, succeeding James Bisgrove, who left for a role in Saudi Arabia. Stewart, who served in various roles at Manchester United over 14 years, including interim CEO, will take over day-to-day operations at Rangers. His appointment follows a leadership void after former chairman John Bennett's health-related resignation and an unsuccessful attempt to hire St Mirren's Jim Gillespie. Meanwhile, Malcolm Offord is expected to be named the new chairman. Stewart's extensive experience, including his time at the UEFA Champions League's commercial agency, positions him to lead Rangers through this transitional phase.

title: Survey reveals number of EV chargers in Fife as network continues to grow

title_detail.value: Survey reveals number of EV chargers in Fife as network continues to grow

author: Allan Crow
generated_summary: A recent survey highlights a significant increase in the number of public electric vehicle (EV) chargers in Fife, with a 36% rise over the past year, bringing the total to 226 chargers as of July. This growth is part of a broader effort to expand EV infrastructure across the UK, aiming to meet the government's target of 300,000 public chargers by 2030. Despite this progress, the RAC has raised concerns about the uneven distribution of chargers, noting disparities in accessibility across different regions. Fife currently has 61 public chargers per 100,000 people, with 45 being rapid chargers. The Department for Transport emphasizes its commitment to accelerating the rollout to ensure widespread access and encourage the transition to zero-emission vehicles.

title: AA warns drivers to do quick 5 step routine to de-frost car

title_detail.value: AA warns drivers to do quick 5 step routine to de-frost car

summary: Drivers are being warned to not drive off until they have completed these five steps

summary_detail.value: Drivers are being warned to not drive off until they have completed these five steps

author: Sophie Buchan
generated_summary: The AA has issued a warning to drivers against using online hacks for de-frosting car windscreens, which can potentially damage vehicles. Instead, they recommend a safe five-step routine: ensure wipers are not frozen, start the engine with warm air directed at the windscreen, remove all snow from the vehicle, use a scraper and de-icer on the outside while the interior warms up, and only drive once the glass is clear. This advice comes in response to ineffective and potentially harmful hacks, such as using hot water, which can crack the glass, or rubbing potatoes on windows, which can cause smearing.

title: Electric cars less likely to breakdown than petrol and diesel models, new report finds

title_detail.value: Electric cars less likely to breakdown than petrol and diesel models, new report finds

summary: AA recorded only five or six EV breakdowns per year due to running out of battery

summary_detail.value: AA recorded only five or six EV breakdowns per year due to running out of battery

author: Hemma Visavadia
generated_summary: A new report reveals that electric vehicles (EVs) in the UK are less prone to breakdowns compared to petrol and diesel models, with only 1.85% of EV-related breakdowns due to battery depletion. This marks a significant improvement from previous years, attributed to advancements in battery technology, increased charging infrastructure, and better driver education. The AA notes that the trend aligns with similar patterns in Norway, which has a high EV adoption rate. The report highlights an 80% reduction in out-of-charge incidents over eight years, suggesting enhanced EV reliability. Despite these improvements, some drivers remain hesitant about transitioning to EVs due to uncertainties about ownership and charging logistics.

The loss underscores the volatility and challenges faced by companies and investors in adapting to the rapidly evolving clean energy market.

title: 'Keep Moving' Signs And The New Hyundai Ioniq 9 In This Week's Car Culture Roundup

title_detail.value: 'Keep Moving' Signs And The New Hyundai Ioniq 9 In This Week's Car Culture Roundup

summary: A collection of our best posts of the week in car culture

summary_detail.value: A collection of our best posts of the week in car culture

author: Jalopnik Staff
generated_summary: This week's Car Culture Roundup highlights several notable automotive stories. Key topics include the unveiling of the 2026 Hyundai Ioniq 9, a three-row electric SUV with a spacious interior and aerodynamic design, showcased ahead of its Los Angeles Auto Show debut. The roundup also features Jake Paul's unique entrance at a boxing match in a custom '90s Chevy truck, the end of MotorTrend's popular "Roadkill" show after 13 seasons, and a nostalgic look at the underrated Ford Flex. Additionally, discussions touch on the challenges of electric vehicle sound design, Bugatti's quest for faster speeds hindered by tire limitations, and potential impacts of proposed tariffs on Mexican imports. The roundup offers a diverse mix of automotive news, from nostalgic reflections to cutting-edge innovations in the industry.

title: WATCH NOW: Footage reveals drivers endangering British bin workers

title_detail.value: WATCH NOW: Footage reveals drivers endangering British bin workers

author: Hemma Visavadia
generated_summary: The article highlights a significant road safety issue in Cornwall, where reckless driving is endangering bin workers. During Road Safety Awareness Week, Cornwall Council released CCTV footage showing vehicles mounting pavements and narrowly avoiding waste collection crews, violating Highway Code rule 145. These dangerous actions, captured over two years, have prompted safety concerns as crews service thousands of properties daily. Biffa, the company operating the service, reports that workers also face verbal abuse. Offenders risk fines and legal action, with such behavior classified under dangerous driving offences. Authorities emphasize the need for patience and consideration on the roads to prevent potential harm to workers and the public.

title: Oxford Bus Company staff raise funds for special school

title_detail.value: Oxford Bus Company staff raise funds for special school

summary: IT WAS their job to keep Oxford buses running on the roads, but they still made time to support worthy causes

summary_detail.value: IT WAS their job to keep Oxford buses running on the roads, but they still made time to support worthy causes

author: Andrew Ffrench
generated_summary: In 1985, staff at the Oxford Bus Company, then known as City of Oxford Motor Services, raised over £3,000 to support local causes, including purchasing a computer for the Mabel Prichard School for handicapped children in Littlemore. Additionally, they allocated £2,050 for a monitor at John Radcliffe Hospital's special care baby unit and £500 for holidays for children at Park Hospital in Headington. The funds were raised through raffles, charity auctions, and a London to Brighton cycle race. Their efforts earned them fifth place in a national fundraising contest, which included a £250 prize that was also donated to charity. The Oxford Bus Company continues to play a vital role in Oxfordshire's public transport, now operating from Watlington Road, Cowley.

title: Number of electric vehicle chargers in Dudley fell by a tenth last year

title_detail.value: Number of electric vehicle chargers in Dudley fell by a tenth last year

summary: The number of public electric vehicle chargers drivers had access to in Dudley fell by a tenth last year, new figures show.

summary_detail.value: The number of public electric vehicle chargers drivers had access to in Dudley fell by a tenth last year, new figures show.

author: Stourbridge News Staff
generated_summary: The number of public electric vehicle (EV) chargers in Dudley decreased by 10% last year, dropping from 198 to 179, according to new Department for Transport figures. This decline raises concerns about inconsistent charger availability across the UK, as highlighted by the RAC. Despite a national increase of 47% in charger installations, Dudley has only 55 public chargers per 100,000 people. The UK government aims to install 300,000 public chargers by 2030, requiring 3,600 new chargers monthly. The RAC emphasizes the need to prioritize areas with poor charger access, noting significant regional disparities, with London having a third of the country's chargers. The Department for Transport remains committed to accelerating charger rollout to support the transition to zero-emission vehicles.

title: The next 12 Norwich streets to get electric car chargers

title_detail.value: The next 12 Norwich streets to get electric car chargers

summary: Work to install electric vehicle charging points on another dozen Norwich streets will begin next week.

summary_detail.value: Work to install electric vehicle charging points on another dozen Norwich streets will begin next week.

author: Dan Grimmer
generated_summary: Norfolk County Council is set to install electric vehicle charging points on 12 additional streets in Norwich, beginning November 25, as part of their 2021 strategy to promote electric vehicle use. The project, in partnership with Blink Charging UK, will add 22 new charge points, with completion expected by February. This initiative follows the installation of 24 charge points in the city, with nearly 200 vehicles charged in the first four months. The council emphasizes the importance of accessible public chargers for residents without private driveways, aiming for a greener future in Norfolk.

title: Norfolk firm launches new department to fulfil international orders

title_detail.value: Norfolk firm launches new department to fulfil international orders

summary: Prior Power Solutions, in Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, has launched a new welding and fabrication department to fulfil a growing number of…

summary_detail.value: Prior Power Solutions, in Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, has launched a new welding and fabrication department to fulfil a growing number of…

author: Adam Barker
generated_summary: Prior Power Solutions, based in Great Yarmouth, has launched a new welding and fabrication department to meet increasing international demand. The company, originally established as Prior Diesel Ltd in 1980 and now part of the Suretank Group, aims to enhance its in-house manufacturing capabilities. This expansion allows Prior Power Solutions to maintain quality control, reduce lead times, and offer more cost-effective solutions. The new department has already completed ten skid frames for the offshore industry, including two acoustic frames built to DNV 2.7-1 standards. Managing Director James Rix highlighted the benefits of recent investments in staff and infrastructure, which have resulted in securing fabrication work globally, including orders from Angola.

title: Changes driven by Musk biggest threat to China under Trump 2.0, adviser warns

title_detail.value: Changes driven by Musk biggest threat to China under Trump 2.0, adviser warns

summary: Greatest pressure to ‘come from changes within the US’, Zheng Yongnian says, urging China to expand opening up as a countermeasure.

summary_detail.value: Greatest pressure to ‘come from changes within the US’, Zheng Yongnian says, urging China to expand opening up as a countermeasure.

author: South China Morning Post
generated_summary: China's greatest challenge during a potential second term for Donald Trump as U.S. president could stem from domestic changes driven by tech mogul Elon Musk, according to Zheng Yongnian, a prominent Chinese political scientist. Zheng advises that China should counteract by expanding its unilateral opening-up strategies, particularly towards the U.S., to gain leverage in the ongoing rivalry. He predicts that while Trump's return might cause short-term economic and trade disruptions for China, it could simultaneously reduce geopolitical tensions. Zheng also warns that Trump's "America First" policy and potential tariff increases could severely harm both U.S.-China relations and the global trade system.
